body.value: FERMANAGH, Northern Ireland â John Sheridan stood ankle deep in the lush grass of his farm tracing the border between the U.K. and the Republic of Ireland with his finger.
"I'm being shoved back into a corner," he said, following the line in a 270-degree arc.
"That boy there," he said, waving in the direction of his 22-year-old son, Chris. "He doesnât remember what it was like when there was a border."
The soldiers, the searches, the checkpoints needing to be traversed to enter local towns, the feeling you're living in a militarized zone. "It was soul destroying," Sheridan recalled.

Like many living in border communities in Northern Ireland -- which is part of the U.K. â and the neighbouring Irish Republic â an independent country -- Sheridan is adamant that Britainâs looming exit from the European Union cannot bring the reinstatement of a physical boundary. That could range from manned customs posts to security cameras. Some fear it would rekindle tensions and even spill over into violence.
